# Machine Placement and Regional Capacity 

**When you scale an app on Fly.io, where your machines land depends on regional capacity. Hereâ€™s how to keep that from surprising you.**

Letâ€™s say you run `fly scale count` and tell it to drop 10 machines into `dfw` and 10 more into `iad`. If either of those regions is out of capacity, *the entire scale operation fails*. Nothing gets placed. Itâ€™s all or nothing.

Most of the time this just worksâ€"`dfw` and `iad` are solid bets for region choices. But some regions, like `sjc`, `gru`, and `bom`, tend to be in high demand. If you hardcode your placement into one of those and cross your fingers, you might find yourself scaling to zero.

### [](#how-to-check-available-capacity)[How to check available capacity] 

Run `fly platform regions`. Youâ€™ll get a list of regions and their available CPU cores. These arenâ€™t guarantees, but theyâ€™re a decent snapshot of where youâ€™re most likely to succeed.

### [](#let-the-scheduler-help)[Let the scheduler help] 

For individual machine operations like `fly machine clone` or creating a new machine, you can give the scheduler some leeway. Instead of pinning a single region, you hand it a prioritized list or a geographic group. It tries each in order until it finds one that works.

For example:

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) [ Wrap text ]

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) [ Copy to clipboard ]

``` highlight
fly machine clone -r "iad,dfw"
```

That says: try `iad`, then fall back to `dfw`.

### [](#geographic-groups-and-aliases)[Geographic groups and aliases] 

You can use geographic aliases like `us`, `eu`, or `sa` to fan out across a broader area.

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)[Wrap text]

  Alias         Area
  ------------- ---------------
  `apac`        Asia-Pacific
  `eu`          Europe
  `na`          North America
  `sa`          South America
  `us`, `usa`   United States

### [](#examples)[Examples:] 

-   Try London first, then fall back to anywhere in Europe:

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) [ Wrap text ]

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) [ Copy to clipboard ]

``` highlight
lhr,eu
```

-   Try any US region first, then Europe:

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) [ Wrap text ]

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) [ Copy to clipboard ]

``` highlight
us,eu
```

-   Try any North American region first, then any South American region:

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) [ Wrap text ]

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) [ Copy to clipboard ]

``` highlight
na,sa
```

### [](#scale-commands-dont-yet-do-this)[Scale commands don't (yet) do this] 

Right now, flexible placement doesnâ€™t apply to `scale`, `deploy`, or `launch`. If you want to scale across regions with fallbacks, the supported way to do that is by cloning machines individually (or using `fly machine create`), with region preferences.

(We know thatâ€™s a bit clunky. Weâ€™re working on it.)

### [](#machines-api-support)[Machines API support] 

If you're driving placement from the Machines API (`api.machines.dev`), all of this flexibility is available there: prioritized region lists, meta-regions, and `any` placement.

### [](#a-word-on-architecture)[A word on architecture] 

This only helps if your app actually works when deployed across multiple regions. That means not assuming low-latency connections between machines, and avoiding coordination patterns that only work in single-region setups.

Want to see where your app might run? Hereâ€™s the [current list](/docs/reference/regions/): ams, arn, bom, cdg, dfw, ewr, fra, gru, iad, jnb, lax, lhr, nrt, ord, sin, sjc, syd, yyz.

### [](#related-reading)[Related reading]

-   [Regions Reference](/docs/reference/regions/)
-   [Fly Machines API](/docs/machines/api/)
-   [Get Regions](https://docs.machines.dev/#tag/platform/get/platform/regions)
